section.p: Historical documents usually have a complex layout, making them one of the most challenging types of documents for automatic image analysis. In the pipeline of automatic document image analysis (DIA), layout analysis is an important prerequisite for further steps including optical character recognition, script analysis, and image recognition. It aims at splitting a document image into regions of interest such as text lines, background, and decorations. To train a layout analysis system, an essential prerequisite is a set of pages with corresponding ground truth (GT), i.e. existing labels (e.g. text line and decoration) annotated by human experts. Although there exist many methods and tools in GT generation, most of them are not suitable on our specific data sets. In this article, we propose to use Gabor features to generate GT, and based on Gabor features, we developed a web-based interface called DivaDiaWI. DivaDiaWI applies automatic functions using Gabor features to generate GT of text lines. For other region types such as background and decorations, users can manually draw their GT with user-friendly operations. The evaluation shows that (1) DivaDiaWI has two advantages when bringing it into context with state-of-the-art tools, (2) the automatic functions of DivaDiaWI greatly accelerate the GT generation, and (3) DivaDiaWI obtains a high score in a system usability test.

div.p: When working with historical documents, it is not uncommon for scholars to have access to digital facsimiles. Thus, access to visual representations of historical documents has become much easier. The increasing amount of digital data available in virtual libraries, such as e-codices1 and manuscript mediaevalia,2 provides new research possibilities, such as comparing digital facsimiles of different repositories and annotating digital images. To handle the data and to perform research tasks on digital facsimiles, scholars need usable tools. The increasing amount of data to be handled furthermore requires an improvement of automatic methods which support the document image analysis (DIA) process. DIA refers to the process of automatically extracting high-level information from digitized images of documents.

Ground truth (GT) is an essential prerequisite for layout analysis, which is the first important step in DIA. The importance of GT is two-fold: first, automatic methods can learn knowledge represented by GT from the experts, and then predict the layout of unseen images. Second, it is used to assess the performance of an automatic method by an evaluation (e.g. accuracy) of the prediction of the method against the GT. An example of a historical document image together with its layout GT is shown in Fig. 1.

In the domain of DIA, ground truthing refers to the process of generating GT. Manual ground truthing is tedious and time-consuming. On our document image data set, it costs 0.5–1.5 h on one image depending on the specifics of the image. Especially, text lines consume about 80% of the ground truthing time. The reason is two-fold. On one hand, each document page contains many text lines (fifty-six lines on average). On the other hand, other elements such as comments and decorations usually occur as only a couple of entities for each page. Thus accelerating the ground truthing of text lines is crucial for the ground truthing of whole pages.

There exist many works in ground truthing in the literature. Lopresti and Nagy (2001) discussed issues in ground truthing graphic documents. They gave an overview of the ground-truthing process and examined whether GT is always well-defined for a given task. In (Hu et al., 2001), the authors presented a detailed analysis of why table ground truthing was hard. They identified some problems in ground truthing including insufficient skill level of the ground truther, restrictions in the model, inadequate interactive tools, shortcomings in the automated table analysis system, and difficulties intrinsic to the table. Antonacopoulos et al. (2006) discussed the issues related to the design, representation, and creation of GT. They released a data set for performance evaluation and associated GT. In (Héroux et al., 2007), the authors proposed an approach for the automatic generation of GT used in DIA and understanding systems. The generated GT includes information of logical structure, formatting rules, layout structure, and reading order. In the field of binarization ground truthing, Smith (2010) compared four evaluation metrics, and explored the variability of the results of five different automatic binarization algorithms. To represent image data, Pletschacher and Antonacopoulos (2010) proposed the PAGE (Page Analysis and Ground-truth Elements) format, which is an XML-based page image representation framework that records information on image characteristics. The PAGE format is also used in our work (see Section 3.1).

To generate GT, there already exist several tools. TrueViz (Lee and Kanungo, 2003) is a Java-based tool for visualizing and editing GT. It works on various operating systems including Windows and UNIX. It uses GT in XML format. However, automatic extraction of text lines is not implemented. PerfectDoc (Yacoub et al., 2005) is a correction tool to correct the output from a document understanding system, with possible application to GT generation. The tool has the advantages of being comprehensive, easy to use, and configurable. However, since PerfectDoc is mainly used for correction rather than ground truthing, it has no automatic function to outline text lines. PixLabeler (Saund et al., 2009) is a Java-based user interface for labeling elements on document images at pixel level. Each foreground pixel is labeled. It provides a function of automatic detection of group structures, e.g. text lines. But the function works well on only documents with regular elements, rather than historical documents. GEDI (Doermann et al., 2010) is a highly configurable document image annotation tool. The metadata is an XML-based representation that represents information at the document, page, and zone levels. It has many functions including merging/splitting functions and reading order. Aletheia (Clausner et al., 2011) is an advanced system for accurate and yet cost-effective ground truthing of large amounts of documents. It supports top-down and bottom-up ground truthing. It allows users to select a zone containing text lines, and automatically obtains the outlines of text lines. Recently a web-based version of Aletheia has become available.3 The authors of WebGT (Biller et al., 2013) claimed that WebGT was the first web-based system to help users produce GT data for document images. The system provides several novel semi-automatic tools that had proven effective for annotating degraded documents. DivaDia (Chen et al., 2015) is a recent Java-based software developed in the DIVA group. DivaDia defines five types of elements: page, text block, text line, decoration, and comment. The GT of these elements is represented by unconstrained polygons.

However, most of the methods and tools mentioned above do not work well on our data sets. They either have no/inefficient function to automatically extract text lines, or represent the GT with rough rectangles, which are not accurate to represent the complex shape of the elements on historical document images.

DivaDiaWI is designed to overcome this issue. The name DivaDiaWI stands for a Web-based Interface for DIA of DIVA group (Document, Image, and Voice Analysis group).4 The biggest advantage of DivaDiaWI is that it is able to automatically draw GT of text lines efficiently. The workflow of DivaDiaWI consists of three modules. Module 1 applies Gabor features to automatically generate GT of text lines represented by polygons. Module 2 is to manually draw GT of other elements, e.g. text block and decoration. Finally, Module 3 is to modify the GT generated from the two previous modules using semi-automatic operations. Another advantage of DivaDiaWI is polygon representation of GT, which means that the GT of a layout region is represented as a polygon. Polygons, which are more complex than rectangles, are an accurate GT representation for layout analysis. In addition, DivaDiaWI is web-based, and thus, it is very convenient for users to use it directly with a browser.

Besides an introduction to the web user interface, the methodological contribution of this article is an efficient workflow for GT generation using Gabor features (Module 1). Gabor features (Jain and Farrokhnia, 1991) are obtained by convolving Gabor filters with an input image. They are powerful for texture classification. In document images, since text is richer than pictures in high-frequency components, Gabor features are often used for text extraction, for example, text extraction from digital document images (Raju et al., 2004, Qiao et al., 2006), Chinese text location under complex background (Yan et al., 2011), text detection in natural scene images (Yi and Tian, 2011), and text detection from videos (Prakash and Ravishankar, 2014). However, to the best of the authors’ knowledge, Gabor features have not yet been used for generating GT of document images. Thus, our innovation is to use Gabor features to automatically extract the contour of text lines, which is the basis of our GT generation. The workflow of Module 1 consists of four steps: (1) clustering pixels represented by Gabor features into text and non-text, (2) splitting vertically attached connected components, (3) merging horizontally connected components, and (4) drawing polygons outlining the text lines. At the end of Module 1, a raw GT of text lines is obtained, which may be further improved later.

The user evaluation shows that DivaDiaWI is an efficient tool. (1) Compared to the state-of-the-art tools, DivaDiaWI has two main advantages (automatically drawing GT of text lines efficiently and polygon representation). (2) Compared to fully manual ground truthing, the automatic functions save around half of the ground truthing time. (3) DivaDiaWI obtains a high score in a system usability test.

The historical document images for this work are from the IAM Historical Document Database (IAM-HistDB),5 which is a repository of data sets that contain handwritten historical manuscript images (Fischer et al., 2011, 2012). The IAM-HistDB repository currently includes three data sets: Saint Gall data set, Parzival data set, and Washington data set.

The Saint Gall data set consists of digital manuscript images that contain the hagiography Vita sancti Galli by Walafrid Strabo. The digital images of the manuscript were made available online by the e-codices project,6 a virtual manuscript library of Switzerland. The Parzival data set contains forty-seven pages of a medieval manuscript originating in the 13th century. An electronic manuscript edition was published on CD-ROM by the German Language Institute of the University of Bern, Switzerland.7 The Washington data set includes pages of letters written by George Washington and his associates in the year 1755.

DivaDiaWI is a web-based interface for ground truthing. It is now publicly accessible at http://diuf.unifr.ch/diva/divadiawi/. It works on the main browsers, e.g. Chrome, Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Opera. A screenshot of the working interface of DivaDiaWI is shown in Fig. 3. A detailed user guide in both text and video is available at http://diuf.unifr.ch/diva/divadiawi/#/userguide. In this section, the GT representation and the workflow of DivaDiaWI are sketched.

To represent GT, we use the same definition proposed in Chen et al. (2015) to define five types of elements on document images: text line, text block, decoration, comment, and page. The text line is the type of regions where the main text is written. The text block incorporates text lines and document background between text lines. The decoration represents decorative elements such as figures, drop capitals, and decorative initials. The comment represents the annotations and inserted text in the margins. Finally, the page outlines only the document part within the scanned image. An example of the five elements is given in Fig. 1b. The contours of the five elements are represented by polygons. All information including polygons and document name is saved in XML files of the PAGE schema (Pletschacher and Antonacopoulos, 2010), a widely used image representation framework for layout analysis.

The system workflow of DivaDiaWI contains three modules. The workflow is illustrated in Fig. 4. Given a set of document images, GT can be generated parallelly using multiple browser windows, each of which processes one image. The first and second modules can run parallelly. The three modules run as follows.

li.p: Module 1. To run Module 1 on an image, users need to manually draw a rectangle for each text block to represent the text block. As soon as the rectangle is drawn, the automatic function running on the server starts. The automatic function applies Gabor features to extract text lines, and this is the most important step in the whole workflow of DivaDiaWI. After Module 1 is done, text lines are automatically represented by polygons and outlined in red on the browser.

Module 2. Since the automatic function in Module 1 is devised specifically for text lines, users need to manually draw GT of page, text blocks, decorations, and comments, which is Module 2. Regarding text lines, alternatively users can also draw GT of text lines completely manually within Module 2.

Module 3. The GT generated by both Module 1 and Module 2 may need to be corrected or modified afterward. Thus Module 3 follows. Module 3 contains semi-automatic modifying functions and manual modifying operations. Semi-automatic modifying functions, including splitting, merging, and cropping, are used specifically to correct the polygons generated from Module 1. Manual modifying operations, including moving a vertex, adding a vertex, and deleting a polygon or rectangle, are used to modify the GT generated from any stage.

div.p: After users finish the work of Module 3, ground truthing is done. Users can save the XML file containing the GT to the hard disk. Later, users can still reload the XML file and modify the GT. The three modules of DivaDiaWI are detailed in the next section.
In this section, the implementation and user interaction of the three modules are elaborated.
div.h3: 4.1 Module 1: Automatically drawing GT of text lines
div.p: Users need to manually draw a rectangle for each text block to run the automatic function. Then the image and the information of the rectangle (x, y coordinates of the top-left vertex, width, and height) are sent to the server. On the server, the subimage within the rectangle is cropped and further processed in four steps: clustering, splitting, merging, and drawing. An example of the images generated after each step is illustrated in Fig. 5. The initial subimage containing a text block is shown in Fig. 5a.

div.h4: 4.1.1 Clustering pixels of the text block into text and non-text
div.p: The first step is to cluster the pixels of the text block into text and non-text. To this end, the method using Gabor filters in Jain and Farrokhnia (1991) is applied. The method is illustrated in Fig. 6. First, the image containing a text block is filtered by a Gabor filter bank, which consists of eighty-four Gabor filters. After image filtering, eighty-four filtered images are obtained. These images are then transformed by a nonlinear sigmoidal function and smoothed by a Gaussian smoothing function. Then eighty-four feature images are obtained. Each pixel of the original text block is represented by an eighty-six-dimension feature vector, where eighty-four dimensions are from feature images and two dimensions are the pixel’s x–y coordinates. The feature vectors are then clustered by k-means algorithm, where k = 2, meaning that the text block is to be segmented into text and non-text. At the end of this step, the image in Fig. 5b is obtained.

The clustering result in Fig. 5b is still not perfect. For instance, a connected component (a group of pixels visually connected) from a text line may be wrongly attached to another connected component from a consecutive line (see an example in Fig. 7a). Then regarding Fig. 7a, a horizontal projection histogram is obtained. The point with the highest intensity is found to horizontally split the connected component (see Fig. 7b). At the end of this step, the image in Fig. 5c is obtained.

The third step is to merge the horizontally connected components within the same line. The merging algorithm first randomly chooses a connected component. Supposing the algorithm chooses the first connected component from the third line of Fig. 5c, we show this connected component and its two following connected components in Fig. 8a. Then the merging algorithm draws two small rectangles on the two sides of the first connected component (see Fig. 8b). Since the right rectangle touches the second connected component, these two connected components should be merged. A red polygon which contains the rectangle and some background is then obtained (see Fig. 8c). Afterward the red polygon is painted and filled in black and thus the two connected components are merged together (see Fig. 8d). The merging algorithm iteratively merges every connected component and their horizontally neighboring connected components. At the end of this step, the image in Fig. 5d is obtained.

div.h4: 4.1.4 Drawing polygons outlining the text lines
div.p: The fourth step is to outline text lines using polygons. A subset of pixels on the boundary of the text line is picked up clockwise with an interval of twenty. Then this subset of pixels is used to construct the polygon. After the construction of the polygons for all of the text lines on the image, the information of these polygons is sent back to the browser. Finally, the browser draws the polygons in red (see Fig. 5e). At the end of this step, Module 1 finishes.

Our text line extraction functions are running on DivaServices (Würsch et al., 2016),8 a framework offering diverse DIA methods as RESTful web services for the research community. RESTful web services (Fielding, 2000) are services based on representational state transfer architecture, which is a web development style aiming for fast performance, reliability, and the ability to scale. Note that also other text line extraction methods are provided by DivaServices. Thus our method can easily be replaced by other methods, making it feasible to use the most suitable method according to the specifics of the images of interest.
div.h3: 4.2 Module 2: Manually drawing GT of other elements
div.p: Since Module 1 is devised specifically for text lines, users need to manually draw GT of other elements, i.e. page, text block, decoration, and comment. Users can also draw GT of text lines manually.

With the menu ‘Draw’ in the menu bar, users can choose to draw an element. Different elements are drawn in different colors (see Fig. 1b). The GT can be represented by both polygons and rectangles. By default, polygons are used to represent GT. When users draw a polygon, a single click creates a vertex of a polygon, and a double click completes the polygon. In addition, if a single click is close enough to the first vertex of the polygon, the polygon is also completed. This feature has proven quite efficient on devices with touch screen. During drawing a polygon, if users want to cancel the last click (vertex), they should press the key backspace. If users choose rectangles to represent GT, the first single click creates a vertex of the rectangle, and the second single click creates the diagonal vertex and also completes the rectangle.

The GT from the two previous modules may need to be corrected or modified. Thus Module 3 is devised to modify the GT. Module 3 includes semi-automatic modifying functions and manual modifying operations. The semi-automatic modifying functions, including splitting, merging, and cropping, are devised specifically to modify the polygons generated by Module 1. To use semi-automatic modifying functions, first users need to specify the polygon to be modified, and the modifying location(s). Then the information is sent to the server. The server runs corresponding algorithm to generate a new polygon, and then sends it back to the browser. Finally the browser replaces the old polygon with the new one. The manual modifying operations, including moving a vertex, adding a vertex, and deleting a polygon or rectangle, are used to modify the GT generated from any stage.

In Module 1, splitting had already been done. However, the algorithm may miss some vertically attached connected components if their heights are below a threshold. In this case, users need to specify the connected component, and the expected position to horizontally split it. Given a vertically attached connected component in Fig. 9a, users need to click the position 1 in Fig. 9b to specify the position where users intend to split it. Finally, two separate connected components are obtained in Fig. 9c.

In this case, users need to specify the two connected components. Users need to click the position 1 to specify the position where users intend to crop the polygon (see Fig. 11b). Finally, a more compact polygon is obtained (see Fig. 11c).

To modify GT, the following operations are available: moving a vertex, adding a vertex, and deleting a polygon or rectangle. Moving a vertex means that users can drag an existing vertex of a polygon or rectangle to a new position. Adding a vertex means that users can add a new vertex to a polygon. Fig. 12a shows a GT generated from a previous module. After being modified manually, a good GT for use is finally generated (see Fig. 12b).

li.p: Automatically drawing GT of text lines efficiently. It is useful if a tool can automatically draw GT of text lines efficiently on the IAM-HistDB. Both TrueViz and PerfectDoc have no automatic function implemented for drawing text lines. PixLabeler can automatically extract text lines, but the accuracy of the obtained text lines on our document data sets is not good enough for the following layout analysis algorithms. Furthermore, since PixLabeler’s GT is pixel-level, each pixel is labeled. But it is difficult to modify the label of each mislabeled pixel. The authors of WebGT claimed that an online semi-automatic function was available to semi-automatically define a considered component’s outline. But the function normally fails on the IAM-HistDB. DivaDia can automatically extract text lines, but obtains only rectangles rather than polygons.

Polygons representation. It is useful if a tool can represent GT with polygons, rather than only rectangles. To justify this criterion, a comparison between rectangle and polygon representations of a text line is shown in Fig. 13. From the figure, it is clear that a polygon is much more accurate than a rectangle to represent a text line for layout analysis. Both PerfectDoc and WebGT represent GT with only rectangles. PixLabeler represents GT at pixel level, using neither polygons nor rectangles. Pixel-level representation is even less suitable than rectangle representation for layout analysis, since the aim of layout analysis is to detect ‘regions’, rather than ‘pixels’.

div.p:
In addition, DivaDiaWI has four features which are beneficial.
It supports multiple image file formats, e.g. PNG, JPEG, and BMP.
It runs independently of operating systems, e.g. Windows, UNIX, and Mac.
It is web-based, so that users can use it directly with a browser.9
It can run on multiple browsers, e.g. Google Chrome, Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Opera.

li.p: Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) schema. It is a useful feature if the GT generated by a tool can be saved in XML files of the TEI schema. TEI is a consortium which collectively develops and maintains a standard for the representation of texts in digital form.10 The TEI Guidelines define and document a markup language for representing the structural, renditional, and conceptual features of text.11 The XML schema defined by TEI Guidelines is used for manuscript description. Although TEI schema is widely used for humanists, it is not compatible with any of the state-of-the-art tools in the field of DIA. Thus it is a gap between humanities and computer science. To fill this gap, the PAGE schema (Pletschacher and Antonacopoulos, 2010) used by DivaDiaWI will be converted to the TEI schema. Furthermore, we are now defining a canonical TEI schema which is useful for automatic and manual DIA.

Performance evaluation. It is a useful feature if a tool allows users to carry out performance evaluation. In the context of layout analysis, performance evaluation is to compare the output of a layout analysis algorithm to GT, to analyze the performance of the algorithm with respect to predefined set of metrics, e.g. accuracy. Only TrueViz implemented performance evaluation. Regarding DivaDiaWI, the evaluation metric proposed in Chen et al. (2015) is to be implemented. Further metrics will be made available in the DivaServices.

Reading order. It is a useful feature if a tool can indicate reading order. Reading order describes the logical order in which the text regions of a page are supposed to be read (Clausner et al., 2011). It reflects the logical information of a page, and is usually visualized using an arrow from one entity to the next. We are building another tool which can be used to annotate the reading order. This feature will be integrated into DivaDiaWI.

Transcription. It is a useful feature if a tool allows users to transcribe the text on images into digital format. The transcribed text can be saved in XML files. An HTML textarea element will be implemented to allow users to type the text, which can be saved together with the GT. In addition, some more recent methods available in the DivaServices will be applied.

div.p: To conduct the questionnaire survey, ten participants were asked to participate. The participants were from our university. Around half of them had no experience in ground truthing before. They were asked to generate GT manually and then by using DivaDiaWI. Note that the pages used in the two approaches were randomly chosen and thus might be from different data sets. The questionnaire mainly includes two questions: the time saved by automatic processing and System Usability Scale (SUS).

As mentioned earlier, the biggest advantage of DivaDiaWI is the ability to automatically detect text lines efficiently. To evaluate how useful this function is, the following question is asked in the questionnaires:
Compared to drawing GT fully manually, what percentage of time did you save thanks to the automatic processing?

The automatic processing refers to Module 1. It is worth noting that the time percentage is only a rough estimation. The average percentage of the saved time is around 54%,12 meaning that the automatic functions greatly accelerate the ground truthing.

The SUS (Brooke, 1996) provides a ‘quick and dirty’, and reliable tool for measuring the usability of products, including hardware, software, Web sites, and applications. It has been widely used as an industry standard, with references in over 1,300 articles and publications. The SUS score of DivaDiaWI is 83 of 100, meaning that DivaDiaWI is an efficient tool.

SUS is a ten-item questionnaire. Each item gets a score ranging from 1 to 5, meaning an opinion ranging from strongly disagree to strongly agree. Five item examples are given below:
I think that I would like to use this system frequently.
I found the system unnecessarily complex.
I thought the system was easy to use.
I think that I would need the support of a technical person to be able to use this system.
I found the various functions in this system were well integrated.

After a participant gives a score to each item, the final SUS score is to be calculated. For Items 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9, the score is the participant’s score minus 1. For Items 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10, the score is 5 minus the participant’s score. Then the scores of all of the ten items are summed. The sum is finally multiplied by 2.5, to make the SUS score have a range of 0–100.

The average SUS score is 68 of 100 (Sauro, 2011), which was obtained from over 5,000 users, 500 studies across a variety of application types including consumer and business software, Web sites, and cell phones.
The SUS score of DivaDiaWI is 83 of 100, according to the questionnaires from the participants.13 This score means that DivaDiaWI is efficient.

In this article, we use Gabor features to generate polygon-based GT for layout analysis of historical document images, and a novel web-based interface DivaDiaWI is presented. Compared to the state of the art, DivaDiaWI has two main advantages. First, DivaDiaWI greatly accelerates ground truthing by automatically generating GT of text lines efficiently using Gabor features. On the IAM-HistDB, the automatic functions saved around half of the ground truthing time. Second, DivaDiaWI uses polygons to represent GT, which are more accurate than rectangles for layout analysis. In summary, the user evaluation shows that DivaDiaWI obtains a high SUS score, meaning that DivaDiaWI is an efficient tool.

However, DivaDiaWI also has drawbacks. In Section 5.1, four missing features (TEI schema, performance evaluation, reading order, and transcription) were listed. For each missing feature, a planned solution has already been given. Among these planned solutions, TEI schema will be implemented with the first priority. In addition, another drawback of DivaDiaWI is that its automatic function for drawing GT of text lines is a bit slow. For example, it costs around 2 min and 50 s for an image from the Parzival data set. One time-consuming part is the k-means clustering of Gabor features explained in Section 4.1.1. In future, we plan to use feature selection method to reduce feature dimension, and thus speed up the algorithm.

It is also worth noting that the automatic functions of DivaDiaWI are not versatile for all types of documents. As explained in Section 4.1.1, the input image of Module 1 is a text block. The automatic function then clusters pixels on the image into text and non-text. It works better if the text block contains neat text lines. It may produce poor results if the text block contains many different elements. For example, in an image containing a table, extraction result of tabular data may be poor due to the existence of columns. In this case, users can still draw GT manually. In future, a follow-up study is planned, where we will investigate what types of documents DivaDiaWI works well on.
